knowledge_graph.title: Caramel
knowledge_graph.description: Caramel is a range of food ingredients made by heating sugars to high temperatures. It is used as a flavoring in puddings and desserts, as a filling in bonbons or candy bars, as a topping for ice cream and custard, and as a colorant commonly used in drinks.

related_questions.question: Can I make caramel with normal sugar?
related_questions.snippet: Sugar Note: Most chefs say that only granulated sugar can be successfully caramelized; other sugars — such as brown sugar and unrefined sugar such as cane sugar — contain impurities that can inhibit caramelization. It's those impurities that can burn before the sugar has time to caramelize.
related_questions.title: "Classic" Caramel Sauce - The Big Swich

related_questions.question: Is caramel just sugar and water?
related_questions.snippet: What's the difference between wet caramel and dry caramel? Wet caramel is made by combining sugar and a liquid and cooking them together, while dry caramel is made from just sugar, heated in a dry pan until it liquefies and browns.
related_questions.title: How to make caramel (without breaking a sweat)

related_questions.question: How to melt sugar without burning it?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Heavy-bottomed pot: A pot with a thick base will distribute heat more evenly, reducing the chance of hot spots that can cause burning.
Medium-sized pot: Using a pot that is appropriately sized for the amount of sugar helps ensure even melting.
Water: Adding a small amount of water (about half the amount of sugar by volume) can help the sugar dissolve and melt more evenly.
Stirring: Continuously stir the sugar and water mixture with a wooden spoon or spatula to prevent sticking and burning.
Wipe down sides: Use a wet pastry brush to wipe down any sugar crystals that form on the sides of the pan, as these can cause uneven melting and burning.
Low heat: Use low heat to melt the sugar slowly and evenly.
Stir constantly: Continue to stir the mixture until the sugar is completely melted.
Monitor color: Pay close attention to the color of the sugar as it melts, as it can quickly go from melted to burnt.
Remove from heat: Remove the pan from the heat as soon as the sugar reaches the desired color or consistency.
Continue cooking: . Opens in new tabIf making caramel, continue cooking the melted sugar, without stirring, until it reaches the desired color and consistency.

Remove from heat and cool: . Opens in new tabOnce the caramel is ready, remove it from the heat and carefully cool it down, either by placing the pan in a bowl of cold water or by pouring it onto a prepared surface.
